Speaker: iggy
Dialogue: Aw Lady, if I looked like you, I'd--

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: C'mon...C'mon...

Speaker: iggy
Dialogue: Keep ya sweatshirt on, Sidney.

Speaker: iggy
Dialogue: Hey, Fresh, the Globe just came in -- Hey, Sidney, want an item for Hunsecker's column?  Two rolls get fresh with a baker!  Hey, hot, hot, hot -- etc.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: Just a minute, Mr. Weldon.  I think...

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: I'm sorry.  I thought that was Mr. Falco returning.  Yes, I'll tell him when he comes in.  I know he's been trying to reach you.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: That's the third time he's called today.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: He wants me to break a leg?

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: I told him you were sure the item would be in Mr. Hunsecker's column in tomorrow's...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: It isn't.  I've just seen the early edition.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: But...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: But what?

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: That makes five days in a row that Mr. Hunsecker's cut you out of his column.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: May I rent you out as an adding machine.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Get me Joe Robard.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Who else phoned?

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: The renting agent and the tailor.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Pay the rent.  Let the tailor wait.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: It won't leave much of a balance in the bank...  Mr. Robard?  Could you locate him?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Watch me run a fifty yard dash with my legs cut off!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Sidney, Joe.  How do you like it? I'm running out of alibis!  No, I asked Hunsecker to withhold the item, until he could give it a fine, fat paragraph.  The column was running over and I didn't want you kissed off with just a line...

Speaker: robard
Dialogue: Oh, stop it, Sidney.  You're from the country, not me.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Now, wait a minute, Joe.  When I saw J.J. last night he said...

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: I wish I could help in some way, Sidney.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Help me with two minutes of silence!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Go home, Sally.  It's late...

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: I hate to see you like this --

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Yes, but as a new subscriber you're under no obligation to take more than three books.  And if you mail the enclosed card within ten days --

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: Sidney, I know you by now.  Don't do a dance with me...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: You mean you don't want the extra free gift of a colorful giant map of the world???

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: Sidney, please, dear, if you feel nervous...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: So what'll you do if I feel nervous? You'll open your meaty, sympathetic arms...?

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: Sid...you got me so...I don't know what...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: You ought to be used to me by now.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: I'm used to you...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Lock up and leave the key.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: If that's for me, tear it up!

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: Take a top coat.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: And leave a tip in every hat-check room in town?

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: Sidney Falco office... Oh, Miss Kay, he tried to reach you.  No, he's at the barbers now.  No, that's held over till the Tuesday column...

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: Don't you ever get messages, Eyelashes?  I called you twice.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Has she been in?  I mean lately, in the last coupla days...?

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: I don't think so.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: You're sure.  Find out for me.

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: Sidney, can I talk to you a minute?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Is Frank D'Angelo around?

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: At the bar - Sidney...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Your nephew doesn't want a drink.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: And with ten percent of his future, you're great, too, Frank.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: See my mother?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Robard's my client.  I did it for him and his club, not your boys.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Frank, I think maybe you lied to me.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: You told me that your boy was washed up with Susie Hunsecker, didn't you?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: You told him that?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: When do these hot-headed boys of yours go on the road?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: That's a nice tour.  All booked?  When was Susie around here last?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Listen, Frank, you'd better make sure you're telling me the truth.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: If you knew Hunsecker as well as I did, you might understand why it's my business.  Maybe you're walking around blind, Frank, without a cane.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: ...and in case you didn't know it, Susie Hunsecker's out there on the back step right now.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Hi!  Susie...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Hello, Chico.  Paul.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Throw a rope round this chick while I go get Steve.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Full house...?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Packin' 'em in.

Speaker: devotee
Dialogue: I'm terribly interested in jazz -- serious jazz.  You studied with Milhaud, didn't you?  This is such an interesting fusion of the traditional, classical form with the new progressive style, I just wanted to ask you how you came to form the group...-

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Well, we just sort of got together.  Maybe if you ask Mr. Katz...He writes the stuff, you know.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Don't waste your time there, man. You've got something better waiting outside...  Susie's out there.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: What did she say...?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: You proposed to her, not me.  Go get your answer...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Steve...I'll...I'll try to make a good wife.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Hi, Fellows.  Where's the Chief?

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Dallas.  Is he around?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Yeah, he's around somewhere. Upstairs, maybe.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: This is big, you know.  Very big! Let's go out later, drink some firewater.  With the boys.  Fred can call Millie and -

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Steve, I'd rather you didn't say anything for a day or two...until I tell my brother...

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: You haven't told him yet...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I'm telling him in the morning after breakfast.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: He isn't going to like it.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: You sure you don't want me to be with you...?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Steve, my brother isn't as bad as he's painted.  He isn't perfect, but -

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: But he isn't going to like this, Susie.  And he makes you nervous, not me.  No, I take that back - he makes me nervous, too.  But I wouldn't give him a second thought if not for you.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Let's forget him and -

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: His stooge, Falco, is around - I saw him walk in.  He's been spying on me for weeks, Susie.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Darling, I don't care - really I don't.  Sidney'd had a secret crush on me for years, but nothing we do is his business -

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: But he could be reporting back to your brother, couldn't he?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Steve, dear, please forget all of this.  What can it matter after tomorrow?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: May I dedicate the next number to you?...And the next, and the next. Every Sunday I'll buy you a new bonnet -

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: If the stores are open -

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: And on Monday, I'll take it off and stroke your light brown hair and -

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: And on Tuesday - Hasenpfeffer. STEVE  How do you think I realized I love you?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I made you write a beautiful song...

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: No, you had me eating that Chinese food!...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Can more than two enjoy this joke...  Hello, Susie, I didn't expect to find you here.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Where's those glossy prints you promised?  Tonight's the latest I can place them -

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: It's cold out here, Susie.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Let me apologize for getting you that press spread.  It's been an honor to serve you gratis.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I get the feeling, Falco, that you're always snooping around...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Steve, stop it please...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Kill me!  Find me a door somewhere - I walked in without knocking!

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I'm feeling too good to fight with you, but that isn't what I said - I said you snoop.  For instance, what were you doing around my hotel the other night?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Begging your pardon, I haven't been down the bowery in years!

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: The next time you want information, Falco, don't scratch for it like a dog - ask for it like a man!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: If you're going home, Susie, I'll drop you off...

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Time for the next set, Chief...

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Just a minute, Chico.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Just so you don't leave me in a minor key.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Don't tell me you started a polka with Leo Bartha?

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: No.  That's what I mean - I'm being fired for what I didn't do.

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: He didn't take his eyes off me all night.  Listening...?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Avidly.  He was staring.

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: Staring.  Consequently, when he approached me on his way out I wasn't surprised, but I didn't let on.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: He was writing a special Sunday piece on...?

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: ...cigarette girls... And naturally -

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: You were thrilled to be interviewed.  Were you "interviewed"?

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: In his apartment -

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: And where was his wife?

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: I don't know - it's a big apartment. But I wasn't interviewed.  In fact, I was totally unprepared for what happened.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: We're old friends, Chickie - quit it!  A big columnist comes in this room, without his ball-and-chain and you make like a delicatessen counter!  What did you think would happen in his house?

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: But, Sidney darling, the man must be out of his mind - it was only eleven o'clock in the morning!

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: For a moment I was so taken aback that I said anything that popped into my sleepy head.  If I'm not mistaken, I even ordered the man out of his own house.

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: That night Mr. Van Cleve calls me into his office here.  He's got nothing against me, he says but he can't afford to antagonize columnists.  I told him I still have Sonny at military academy, but Van Cleve's made of ice...

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: Do you think you could do something, Sidney?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: That's what I'm thinking, Rita. Maybe...

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: Do you still keep your key under the mat?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Can you be there by two-thirty?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Frank, I don't want any secrets from you.  I proposed to Susie tonight.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: You don't like it, do you.  I think she will accept, but I'm not sure. She may be too dependent on her brother.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: You're touchy, Sidney - don't be so touchy...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Wanna bite to eat?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Feels like a Monday night, don't it...?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I wish you and Steve could like each other.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: We stick in each others craw.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Yes, but why?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Well, for one thing, he thinks J.J. is some kind of monster.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Don't you?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Susie, your brother's one of my best friends, and -

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I know.  But someday I'd like to look into your clever mind and see what you REALLY think of him -

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Where do you come off to make a remark like that?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Who could love a man who keeps jumping through burning hoops, like a trained poodle?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Do you think J.J. likes Steve...?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Frankly, yes, to my surprise.  He thinks he's very gifted - those boys'll go a big mile, he thinks.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: You feel pretty strong about this boy?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Wedding bells, you mean?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: He wants me to go on the road with them.  It's an eight month tour, all the way to Oregon...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Well, congratulations.  But don't go just for the ride!  Or didn't you accept the proposal?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I'm going to discuss it with J.J. in the morning.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: It's given me a big lift to know that some people want me for myself, not just because I'm my brother's sister.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Chickie, I'll have to laugh at that - an attractive girl like you...!

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I hope that J.J. really likes Steve, that it isn't an act.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Why should he put on an act?  Your brother has told PRESIDENTS where to go and what to do!

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: The act would be for my sake, not Steve's...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Wait for me.  I'll be right back.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: It's not my nature, Susie, but I'll talk to you like an uncle...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: But I don't need an uncle, Sidney.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: No, I mean because I admire you - in fact, more than admire you - although that's neither here nor there.  Susie, don't sell your brother short.  Talk this over with him, I mean - you'll find him a real friend.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Any message, in case I see J.J. later?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Yes.  Tell him for me that Steve Dallas is the first real man I've ever been in love with...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: The Twenty One Club.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Jimmy!  This is a coincidence.  I am just going -

Speaker: weldon
Dialogue: This is my press agent, Joan.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: I tried to reach you twice -

Speaker: weldon
Dialogue: What do you do for that hundred a week.  Fall out of bed?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Jimmy, I'm on my way inside right now to talk to Hunsecker.  I can promise you -

Speaker: weldon
Dialogue: Joan, call a cop!  We'll arrest this kid for larceny!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Listen, when your band was playing at Roseland -

Speaker: weldon
Dialogue: That was two months ago.  Take your hand out of my pocket, thief!

Speaker: the girl
Dialogue: Take it easy, Jimmy dear...

Speaker: weldon
Dialogue: Why?  It's a dirty job, but I pay clean money for it, don't I?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: No more you don't!  What is this - You're showing off for her?  They're supposed to hear you in Korea?

Speaker: weldon
Dialogue: He's intuitive - he knows he's getting fired!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: If you're funny, James, I'm a pretzel!  Drop dead!

Speaker: weldon
Dialogue: It was nice knowing you, Sidney. Not cheap - but nice.  Happy unemployment insurance.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: How are you tonight, Mr. Falco?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Is "he" inside?

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: But of course...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Alone or surrounded?

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: A Senator, an Agent and Something - With - Long - Red - Hair.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Honey, get me Mr. Hunsecker.

Speaker: operator
Dialogue: He's right inside, Mr. Falco.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: So it isn't Long Distance.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: J.J.?  It's me --

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: J.J., it's Sidney.  Can you come outside for one minute?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: I have to talk to you, alone, J.J., that's why.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Can I come in for a minute?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: I'll check it in the morning, Low - thanks.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Harvey, I often wish I were dead and wore a hearing aid...with a simple flick of a switch I could shut out the greedy murmur of little men...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: J.J., I need your ear for two minutes...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Mac!  I don't want this man at my table...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: I have a message from your sister.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Forgive me, Harvey.  We were interrupted before -

Speaker: senator
Dialogue: Err...the Supreme Court story, I was telling you - Justice Black.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Yes, the Justice, that's right. But I think you had it in the column.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Last July, the lead item...

Speaker: senator
Dialogue: And I believe that's precisely where I read it, too.  You see, J.J., where I get my reputation for being the best-informed man in Washington.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Now don't kid a kidder.

Speaker: senator
Dialogue: I don't think we caught your name, young man.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Sidney Falco, sir.  And, of course, everyone knows and admires you, Senator Walker.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: I know Manny Davis.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: ...except MRS. Manny Davis.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Yes?  Go ahead, Billy - shoot...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Uh huh.  Sports cars in California are getting smaller and smaller...the other day you were crossing Hollywood Boulevard and you were hit by one...you had to go to the hospital and have it removed...  You're not following the column: I had it last week.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Do you believe in capital punishment, Senator?

Speaker: senator
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: A man has just been sentenced to death...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Manny, what exactly are the UNSEEN gifts of this lovely young thing that you manage...?

Speaker: agent
Dialogue: Well, she sings a little...you know, sings...

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Manny's faith in me is simply awe- inspiring, Mr. Hunsecker.  Actually, I'm still studying, but -

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: What subject?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Singing, of course...straight concert and -

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Why "of course"?  It might, for instance, be politics...

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Me?  I mean "I"?  Are you kidding, Mr. Hunsecker?  With my Jersey City brains?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: The brains may be Jersey City, but the clothes are Trainor-Norell.

Speaker: senator
Dialogue: Are you an actor, Mr. Falco?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: That's what I was thinking.  Are you, Mr. Falco?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: How did you guess it, Miss James?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: He's so pretty, that's how.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Mr. Falco, let it be said at once, is a man of FORTY faces, not one, none too pretty and ALL deceptive. See that grin?  It's the charming street urchin's face.  It's part of his "helpless" act - he throws himself on your mercy.  I skip the pleading nervous bit that sometimes blends over into bluster.  The moist grateful eye is a favorite face with him - it frequently ties in with the act of boyish candor: he's talking straight from the heart, get it?  He's got about half-a-dozen faces for the ladies, but the real cut one to me is the quick dependable chap - nothing he won't do for you in a pinch.  At least, so he says!  Tonight Mr. Falco, whom I did not invite to sit at this table, is about to show in his last and most pitiful role: pale face with tongue hanging out. In brief, gentlemen and Jersey Lilly, the boy sitting with us is a hungry press agent and fully up to all the tricks of his very slimy trade!

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Match me, Sidney...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Not just this minute, J.J....

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: I know - that loafer of yours opens at the Latin Quarter next week.  Say goodbye, Lester!

Speaker: senator
Dialogue: May I ask a naive question, Mr. Falco?  Exactly how does a press agent work...?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Why don't you answer the man, Sidalee?  He's trying to take you off the hook.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: You just had a good example of it. A press agent eats a columnists dirt and is expected to call it manna.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: What's manna?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Heaven dust.

Speaker: senator
Dialogue: But don't you help columnists by furnishing them with items?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Sure, columnists can't get along without us.  Only our good and great friend, J.J., forgets to mention that.  We furnish him with items -

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: What, some cheap, gruesome gags?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: You print them, don't you?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Yes, with your clients' names attached.  That's the only reason those poor slobs pay you - to see their names in my column all over the world!  Now, as I make it out, you're doing ME a favor!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: I didn't say that, J.J.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: The day that I can't get along without press agents' handouts, I'll close up shop, lock, stock and barrel and move to Alaska.

Speaker: agent
Dialogue: Sweep out my igloo, here I come.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Look, Manny, you rode in here on the Senator's shirt tails, so shut your mouth!

Speaker: senator
Dialogue: Now, come, J.J., that's a little too harsh.  Anyone seems fair game for you tonight.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: This man is not for you, Harvey, and you shouldn't be seen with him in public.  Because that's another part of a press agents life - he digs up scandal among prominent men and shovels it thin among the columnists who give him space.

Speaker: senator
Dialogue: There is some allusion here that escapes me...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: We're friends, Harvey - we go as far back as when you were a fresh kid Congressman, don't we?

Speaker: senator
Dialogue: Why does everything you say sound like a threat?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Maybe it's a mannerism - because I don't threaten friends, Harvey. But why furnish your enemies with ammunition?  You're a family man. Someday, with God willing, you may wanna be President.  Now here you are, Harvey, out in the open where any hep person knows that this one...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: ...is toting THAT one...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: ...around for you...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: ...Are we kids or what?...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Next time you come up, you might join me at my TV show.

Speaker: senator
Dialogue: Thank you, J.J., for what I consider sound advice.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Go, Thou, and sin no more.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Mac, don't let the Senator pay that check...

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: I'll take care of it, Mr. Hunsecker.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: President!  My big toe would make a better President!

Speaker: attendant
Dialogue: Mr. Hunsecker's coat, Joe.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Find me a good one, Joe.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Dan, anyone calls, tell 'em I'll be at the Morocco, maybe the Embers.

Speaker: dan
Dialogue: Very good, Mr. Hunsecker.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Where's your coat, Sidalee?  Saving tips?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: My curiosity is killing me; what are you so rambunctious about tonight?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: There's your fat friend.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Hello, Harry.

Speaker: kello
Dialogue: Bonna sera, commendatore.  Come sta?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: You see, Sidalee, that shows that Lt. Kello likes your people.

Speaker: kello
Dialogue: It's my Brooklyn background, J.J. I'm good on Yiddish, too.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Harry, am I supposed to say "uncle"?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Anything fit to print, tonight?  Hello, Phil.  How're the kids.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Fine, Mr. Hunsecker.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Any news fit to print tonight?

Speaker: kello
Dialogue: I just checked "downtown".  Quiet everywhere tonight.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Incidentally, what happened to that doll? - You gave me the item last night.  Still alive?

Speaker: kello
Dialogue: Yeah.  At Bellevue.  Still hanging on.  But they still don't know if she was pushed.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: She mighta jumped.  Love suicide?  Check it for me, Phil...it's a real heart throb.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Say hello to Sidney Falco.  Tickle him - he's been a bad boy tonight. He called you my fat friend.

Speaker: kello
Dialogue: I don't believe it.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: I know...I know you're the strongest cop in town.

Speaker: kello
Dialogue: I call him the boy with the ice cream face!

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Say, that's good - it's nice - in fact, it's APT, Harry!

Speaker: kello
Dialogue: Yeah, I got eyes.  I put things together.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: I remember ONCE when you didn't quite "put things together".  Boy! Was the Mayor mad!

Speaker: kello
Dialogue: Citizens committees!  I didn't mean to hit the boy that hard.  Yeah, that's when a feller needed a friend and I won't forget his initials, J.J.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: She died twenty minutes ago, Mr. Hunsecker.  They're still investigating.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: See you.

Speaker: kello
Dialogue: Hasta La Vista, J.J.  Hasta Luego.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Spahish...that must show he likes "spigs", too.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: I like Harry, but I can't deny he sweats a little.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: I love this dirty town.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Conjugate me a verb, Sidney.  For instance, TO PROMISE!

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: You told me you'd break up that romance - when?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: You want something done, J.J., but I doubt if you yourself know what's involved.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: I'm a schoolboy - teach me, teach me.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Why not break it up yourself?  You could do it in two minutes flat.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Now, be warned, son - I'll have to blitz you...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Frankly, J.J., I don't think you got the cards to blitz me.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: I don't?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Correct me if I'm wrong, but I don't think so...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: I'll listen one more minute.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: About a year ago, you asked me to do a favor.  It was a thing - well, I never did a thing that dirty in all my life.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Awright, that brings us up to five weeks ago. "Sidney, I got a nasty little problem here." Did I say no? I'm frank to admit - it don't jell as fast as we like... But all of a sudden I CAN'T GET YOU ON THE PHONE NO MORE!  WHY?... And why, as of this date, am I frozen out of the column...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Are you finished?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: No, lemme finish.  I DON'T LIKE THIS JOB!  That boy is dumb only on matinee days - otherwise he's got a head.  And Susan, like you said, she's growing up.  Two heads. What I mean, we got a slippery, dangerous problem here!

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Not "we", Sidney, you!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Correct me if I'm wrong - WE! Because when I'm out on this very slippery limb for you, you have to know what's involved.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Ha!  My right hand hasn't seen my left hand for thirty years!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: I'll do it, J.J. - don't get me wrong - in for a penny, in for a pound.  I'll see it through, but stop beating me around the head. Let me make a living!

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: What you promised - do it!  Don't finagle around.  It's later than you think.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Excuse it, but it's later than you think.  That boy proposed tonight.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Susie told you that...?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: No wonder you've been so 'feisty' tonight.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Can you deliver?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Uh huh.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: When?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Tonight.  Before you go to bed. The cat is in the bag and the bag is in the river.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Don't be a two time loser, Sidalee. The sentence could be severe...

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Hello, Sidney.  Wanna table?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Just hopping tonight.  Leo Bartha been in?

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Yeah, having supper with the Mrs. She's over there.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: He's somewhere...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Thanks, I see him...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Hello, Leo.  How goes that Sunday piece on cigarette girls?

Speaker: bartha
Dialogue: Who told you about it?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: The cigarettes girl...Rita.  And she took out all her hairpins, too.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: I never had the pleasure of meeting your wife.  You know what I wonder, Leo?  Could you use a hot little item for tomorrow's column?

Speaker: bartha
Dialogue: What is this, blackmail?  Beat it!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Leo, I've never had the pleasure of meeting your wife...

Speaker: bartha
Dialogue: Loretta...Sidney Falco...

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: How do you do, Mr. Falco.  If you know anything about horses, sit a minute.  Help yourself to a glass of this N.Y. State champagne - that's what my husband buys me.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: All the imported wines aren't what they're cracked up to be.

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: Whose side are you on, Mr. Falco, his or mine?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Frankly, Mrs. Bartha, I'm a neutral observer for the United Nations.

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: What's your first name?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Sidney.

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: No horse running tomorrow by that name...

Speaker: bartha
Dialogue: You ought to stop this nonsense, Loretta, these two dollar bets.

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: Sidney, did you hear the story about the cloak-and-suitor who -- ?

Speaker: bartha
Dialogue: That's right!  Tell him, so I can read it in Hunsecker's column first!

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: Oh, are you a spy for the other side?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: No, I actually sat down to give Leo an item.

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: Leo, he wants to give you an item - don't be sullen.

Speaker: bartha
Dialogue: Will you mind your own business!

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: Hitler!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Just in case you'd like to print it, Leo.  It's a blind - no names mentioned.  But for your private information, the guy's name is Dallas.

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: There isn't a single name here that gives off vibrations...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Anything there with a name like "cigarette girl"?

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: MMmmmm..."cigarette girl"... No, no horse with a name like that...

Speaker: bartha
Dialogue: I don't print blind items.

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: What is this, chess or checkers...?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: He likes to use the real names...

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: Where are we running?  What am I missing here?

Speaker: bartha
Dialogue: Waiter, the check.  This man is trying to hold a gun to my head!

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: That's the horse!  Shotgun - Shotgun in the fifth!

Speaker: bartha
Dialogue: What do you want to tell my wife, Sidney...?

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: He wants to tell me that you poured champagne all over my lap.

Speaker: bartha
Dialogue: Go on, tell her, I'm waiting!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: What are you talking about?  Are you nuts or what?

Speaker: bartha
Dialogue: Lorry, I can't let this man blackmail me...

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: Blackmail...?

Speaker: bartha
Dialogue: He wants me to print a dirty smear item for keeping his mouth shut

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: About what?

Speaker: bartha
Dialogue: Foolishly, Lorry, and I hope you'll understand... this cigarette girl...I was kidding around with her...this girl, I mean...I was kidding around and she took it seriously.  It was a case of bad judgment, Lorry, bad taste...and I'm just sorry, Lorry, that's all...

Speaker: bartha
Dialogue: Your friend Hunsecker - you can tell him for me - he's a disgrace to his profession.  Never mind my bilious private life - I print a decent, responsible column - that's the way it stays!  Your man - there's nothing he won't print if it satisfies his vanity or his spite!  He'll use any spice to pepper up his daily garbage!  Tell him I said so and that, like yourself, he's got the morals of a guinea pig and the scruples of a gangster!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: What do I do now?  Whistle "The Stars and Stripes Forever?"

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: What you do now, Mr. Falco, is crow like a hen - you have just laid an egg.

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: Leo, this is one of the cleanest things I've seen you do in years...

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: Otis Elwell wants to see you, Sidney.

Speaker: elwell
Dialogue: Hey, wait a minute!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: I'm late for a date with a dame.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Otis, if you're trying to blow this brawl into an item for your column - forget it!

Speaker: elwell
Dialogue: How is dear old J.J. by the way?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Call him up and ask - he might drop dead with shock.

Speaker: elwell
Dialogue: If it were that easy, you wouldn't find an empty phone booth for the next two hours...

Speaker: elwell
Dialogue: ...Talk of a wake! - they'd club each other to cater the affair for free!

Speaker: elwell
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: You don't know that lunatic yet? Whims - egotistic whims!  Like the gag - when you got him for a friend, you don't need an enemy!  That's what the fight with Bartha was about. "Leo", I says, "Hunsecker froze me out.  So I'm eating humble pie this month - please print me an item."

Speaker: elwell
Dialogue: And, instead, he printed his heel in your face?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: I see you're full of human feelings...

Speaker: elwell
Dialogue: Like most of the human race, Sidney, I'm bored.  I'd go a mile for a chuckle...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: ...and two miles for a pretty girl...?

Speaker: elwell
Dialogue: Three...even four...

Speaker: elwell
Dialogue: Then you're really washed up with Hunsecker...?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: This is how much I'm washed with J.J....

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Look, Otis, I make no brief for my bilious private life, but he's got the morals of a guinea pig and the scruples of a gangster.

Speaker: elwell
Dialogue: Who's it about?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: A kid named Dallas, who runs a dinky jazz quintet.  He keeps company with J.J.'s screwball sister...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: It's a real goody if, like me, you wanna clobber J.J.!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: He's got his TV tomorrow.  He'd read it just before rehearsals.

Speaker: elwell
Dialogue: Mmm.  Trouble is I can't think of any good reason why I should print anything you give me.  I can't even think of a bad reason.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Suppose I introduce you to a lovely reason, Otis.  One that's good and bad...and available?

Speaker: elwell
Dialogue: I'm not an unreasonable man...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Waiter!  The check.

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: Hi!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Rita, say hello to Otis Elwell.

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: elwell
Dialogue: Friends call me Otis - sometimes Tricky Otis.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Otis was outraged when I told him Van Cleve was going to fire you. Tell him not to pay any attention to anything you-know-who says about you-know-what.  Right, Otis?

Speaker: elwell
Dialogue: Right!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: I thought you two could talk the whole thing over till I got back.

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: Back?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: One of those business meetings, honey - always coming up in the middle of the night.

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: Hold on.  You can drop me off on your way...

Speaker: elwell
Dialogue: Consternation reigns...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Now, Otis...

Speaker: elwell
Dialogue: I hate J.J. -- but not that much at this moment...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Give me a chance --

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Don't you know who that man is?

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: Yeah.  Otis Elwell.  The columnist.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Yeah!

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: And he's a perfect stranger to me.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: So take five minutes!  Get acquainted!  He's an important man - he's lonely - don't be dumb!

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: What do you want all of a sudden - Lady Godiva...?  Where's my other shoe?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: What kind of an act is this?

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: Don't you think I have any feelings? What am I?  A bowl of fruit?  A tangerine that peels in a minute?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Here's your shoe, there's your coat, that's the door!

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: Sidney...I...I don't do this sort of thing...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: What sort of thing?

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: This sort of thing!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Didn't you ask me to do something about your job?  Don't you have a kid in Military School?

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: You're a snake, Falco.  You're a louse, a real louse.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Honey - he's going to help you! You want to lose your job?

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: A girl needs a little romancing before she -

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Next time I'll call in a guy to paint silver stars on the ceiling!

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: What would you think of me if -

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Nothing I didn't think of you before.

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: - that's what I mean!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: How many snorts does it take to put you in that Tropical Island Mood?

Speaker: elwell
Dialogue: Havana!  That's where we met!

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: Here's mud in your column!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Blessings on thee, the both...well... Gotta run now.  See you two kids later!

Speaker: elwell
Dialogue: Hurry back.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Don't do anything I wouldn't do. That gives you lots of leeway.

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: Palm Springs.  Two years ago.

Speaker: elwell
Dialogue: That's right!

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: Don't tell Sidney.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: It's an item - I hear he goes out with three-eyed girls.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: We shall see what we shall see...  And don't ever use this apartment phone again; I have a nervous sister.

Speaker: news vendor
Dialogue: The Globe?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Gimme The Record.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I have no power to retract, Mr. Cummings... I'm only Mr. Hunsecker's secretary.  No.  Nor can I agree that can retraction is necessary. Thank you for calling.

Speaker: lawyer
Dialogue: I fail to see what's amusing about these papers.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I'll get the boss to sign them.

Speaker: lawyer
Dialogue: They're important.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You've said that six times - that's why I'm smiling.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Hello, Mary, me darlin' and phwat are ye up to today?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: That's a question I usually like to ask YOU.  Your secretary phoned.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: What about?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Something about a Frank D'Angelo trying to reach you...

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Is that the man who manages Susie's boyfriend?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Have you seen this?  In Otis Elwell's column.  "The dreamy marijuana smoke of a lad who heads a highbrow jazz quintet is giving an inelegant odor to that elegant East Side Club where he works.  That's no way for a card-holding Party Member to act. Moscow won't like, you naughty boy!"

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Sally?  I got the message.  If D'Angelo calls again, tell him I'll be at the office around noon.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Could this be that boy?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Dallas?  Could be.  He doesn't look like a reefer smoker...

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: If this is true, J.J.'s going to hit the ceiling...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Can it be news to you that J.J.'s ceiling needs a plaster job every six weeks?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Sidney, you know that J.J. doesn't like people to look at the column proof in advance...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Mary, I'm not "people" - there's Falco blood, sweat and tears in that column.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: How about dinner tonight?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Bribing me again?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: And why should I bribe the woman who holds most of my heart?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You're a real rascal, Sidney.  I'd certainly dislike you if I didn't like you.  You're an amusing boy, but there isn't a drop of respect in you for anything alive - you're too immersed in the theology of making a fast buck.  Not that I don't sometimes feel that you yearn for something better...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Mary, don't try to sell me the Brooklyn Bridge.  I happen to know it belongs to the Dodgers.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I don't mind you looking at the proof of the column in advance, as long as J.J. doesn't know.  But don't do it like a boy stealing gum from a slot machine.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Who put this item in about the comic?  "If there's a more hilarious funny man around than Herbie Temple at the Palace, you'll have to pardon us for not catching the name.  We were too busy screaming." Does this Temple have a press agent?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: No.  It's one of J.J.'s occasional beau gestes.  Evidently the fellow's funny, so he gave him a plug.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: What's your favorite ribbon to go around your favorite chocolates?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Let's wait till Christmas - it's more legitimate then.

Speaker: doorman
Dialogue: Hey!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Herbit Temple here yet?

Speaker: doorman
Dialogue: Yeah, but you can't come in now!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: I'm in, Sonny Boy!

Speaker: evans
Dialogue: I didn't waste words, Herbie, take my word.  I says, "look, Figo, I'm not selling you a dozen eggs, I'm selling you HERBIE TEMPLE", I says, so don't gimme your lip!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Hiya, Al!

Speaker: evans
Dialogue: Since when did you two get acquainted?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: How do you do, Mr. Temple...

Speaker: evans
Dialogue: Delighted.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: I'm Sidney Falco.

Speaker: temple
Dialogue: Yeah, delighted...

Speaker: evans
Dialogue: Watch this guy, Herbie, he's a press agent.

Speaker: temple
Dialogue: You watch him, Al, I s...s...stutter!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Temple, I caught your act the other night and -

Speaker: temple
Dialogue: Did you now?  On which bounce?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: - and I just had to drop by and tell you how great I thought you were.

Speaker: temple
Dialogue: Cheers.  What time is it, Al?

Speaker: evans
Dialogue: You got ten minutes.  Hope you don't mind, Falco: we're busy and if -

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: No, I don't mind.  I'm busy too.

Speaker: temple
Dialogue: Good!  We're all off to Utica, so excuse me, Mr. Frannis-on-the- Portisan.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: But can I ask one impertinent question here?  With no criticism intended, because I know, Al, you earn your ten percent, how come you let a sock act like Herbie Temple tip-toe through town without a publicity build...?

Speaker: evans
Dialogue: We're not buying it, Falco - no fish today.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: I'm not selling.  I'm just curious, that's all.

Speaker: temple
Dialogue: Answer the man, Al, if he asks you a question.  Quick, before he thinks up another!

Speaker: evans
Dialogue: Mr. Temple doesn't believe in press agents - does that answer you something?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Take your hand off, lump!  No one believes in press agents, Temple, when they make claims they can't perform.  I got nothing to sell - I didn't come here to peddle - but if I tell a client that Hunsecker will give him space, it's not just talk!

Speaker: evans
Dialogue: Listen, you bull artist - !

Speaker: temple
Dialogue: Let him go, Al...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Hello?  Mary, let me speak to J.J., please...it's Sidney Falco...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Tell him it's important...

Speaker: gloria
Dialogue: What?  Is this Sidney?...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Sure, I'll wait...

Speaker: evans
Dialogue: Look, nobody hired you!  We didn't talk any deal, and -

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Relax, lump!  I told you I'm not selling fish...  No, not a relative, but important...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Yeah, if you got a pencil there I'll suggest a word or two. Uh...uh...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: It's sweet of you, J.J., thanks. Probably see you at Twenty One tonight.  No, for supper, late. Right. 'Bye...

Speaker: temple
Dialogue: Speak to this lad, Al, ... to Mr. Falco.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: See me in my office.

Speaker: temple
Dialogue: Wait a minute.  Al makes all my deals.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Temple, you've been three passes behind for twenty years.  This could start you off big - T.V. and anywhere.

Speaker: temple
Dialogue: And it would cost a pretty penny, huh?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: You tell him, I stutter!

Speaker: evans
Dialogue: Uh...Why don't we wait till tomorrow?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Wait as long as you like - you know where my office is.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: What is here, a wake?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: You read as you run, don't you?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: It's a habit with me.  So now I'm briefed.  So what?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Frank thinks I shouldn't have come here -

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I thought you might have a faint idea of how this item originated.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Why me...?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Why not you?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: That's your idea of logic?  I tell the Judge I didn't murder the man - the Judge says, "Why not you?"

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Only two men in this town could be responsible for that smear - you or Hunsecker or both.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Dallas, ask your own manager - he's standing here like a pained wolfhound - Hunsecker and Elwell are enemies to the knife.  So how do you get him doing J.J. a favor?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: It is a favor, isn't it?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Dallas, your mouth is as big as a basket and twice as empty!  I don't like you, comma, but neither do I go along with this column saying you smoke marijuana and belong with the Reds.  Also, since we're talking repulsive, J.J. won't like this for two cents!  Don't give me that look, Dallas - J.J. believes in fair play.  And secondly, this could splatter his sister with rotten egg by implication - your her boyfriend!

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: You're talking very fast.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: How do you like it?  He comes to my office and -

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Don't apologize for me, Frank!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Should I cry...?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Then what are you doing here?  Go over there and fight!  If Van Cleve fires your boy, it gives a lie the ring of truth!

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I want to speak to Miss Hunsecker, please.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: What are you calling her for...?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: This is Steve, Susie.  Don't be alarmed, Susie, but I want you to look at Elwell's column in The Record...today...No, about me...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: A smear?...What...What kind of smear...?  Where are you?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: We're on our way to the Elysian Room to dicker with Van Cleve - he's fired us already.  I'll call you later, dear... 'Bye!...

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Come on, Frank.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: What are you looking at...?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Tell him.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: What's the matter?

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: Nothing...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: You know, Sally, sometimes I get the impression you think you live in Star-Bright Park.  This is life, kid - get used to it!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Nikko, is Mr. Hunsecker there? This is Mr. Falco.  Well, have him call me as soon as he can.  It's important.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Did you send my folks in Philly the check...?

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: I put a lotta trust in you, Chickie...

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: I know you do, Sidney.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Don't judge a situation where you don't know what's involved...

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: I'm not judging...

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: I swear, Sidney, I can't help it - sometimes I wonder what I see in you...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: That's no way to talk...

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: Or what you see in me, for that matter...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Stay down town tonight.  Maybe we'll take in a show, etc.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: If you want me to -

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: You see?  Hunsecker's gotta phone ME!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: No, no medals - not yet.  Oh, it's worse than that - Aunty Van Cleve is firing them...from the horse's mouth... They were just here - in a panic...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Who was just there?  You'll be the death of me.  Sidalee! Why?  Didn't you just tell me that they've already traced this smear to you?  All they have to do now is to put two and two together and I'm a chicken in a pot!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: J.J., peace on earth, good will to men - it's working out just the way I planned.  Yeah, I guarantee this bomb will pop right on schedule, but you have to play your part - you be a Saint and let me be the Devil.  But I wanna talk to you first...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Don't come here.  Susie is up and about.  He called her?  You'd better see me at the TV - three o'clock.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: What are you going to do?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Chickie, a lotta people think they're smart.  You watch.  They're dumb: they'll do the work for me! Just watch.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: The table can wait.  No calls.  I have to think about my TV show.

Speaker: nikko
Dialogue: Pleased to do.  I will come back later. HUNSECKER  Did you put the bread out on the terrace for the birds?

Speaker: nikko
Dialogue: Yes, but they don't come no more this time of year.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Susie!  Come in a minute, dear...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Susie, you're very much in my thoughts today.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: What a question, dear, with that newspaper in your hand...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Did Sidney tell you about it?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Yes, he phoned.  I don't know this boy too well.  Anything in these charges?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Not being partial, are you?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: No, I'm not.  I'm not!

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Susie, take it easy.  I'll trust your judgment - you don't have to protest with me.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Why are you trembling, dear...?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: History repeats itself.  Everything that happened to Alan Leslie...began with a smear like this...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Yes...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: It's just as if I've seen a ghost today...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: But that wasn't your fault, dear, what happened to Leslie.  I've told you that a million times...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Then whose fault was it, J.J.?  It was someone's fault, wasn't it?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: I wouldn't have called the boy exactly balanced...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I'm not fighting with you, puss...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: He never would have killed himself if I hadn't gone through with the annulment.  Don't you see that made all the rumors seem true?  I should have stood up for him...not run out.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: J.J., I want you to get them back their job, Steve and the Quintet.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: You mean they've been fired already, on the basis of this crude smear?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Susie, you're sure there isn't some fire where there's this much smoke?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: I know Steve.  No.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Then maybe you can tell me if he's as solid as you say, why does he rap me every chance he gets?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Sidney is a liar!

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Who said Sidney?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I said Sidney!...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: You know, dear, we're drifting apart, you and I, and I don't like that.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I thought we were talking about Sidney?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Let me finish, dear.  You had your say, now let me have mine...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I haven't said anything yet, J.J., but if -

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: I started to say we're drifting apart.  A year ago, in your wildest dreams, would you have walked by that door without taking up this situation with me?  Today I had to call you in!

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I'm taking up the situation with you now...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Susie, I want to help you--, there's nothing I won't do for you. You're all I've got in the whole, wide world.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Well, what have I got?  Alimony to a pair of tramps?  They're of no concern to me.  It's you who count, but don't get me wrong - I don't intend to let you break your neck again!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: J.J., you said you want to help me - prove it!

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Get Steve back his job...please...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: He means that much to you...?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: With your "prestige" it only takes a minute - ten cents worth of American Tel and Tel.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: You're picking up my lingo, hon.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: I read your column every day...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Susie, I like this new attitude of yours.  You're growing up and I like it!  I don't like it when you're limp and dependent, when you're odd and wayward.  This gives you a chance for real survival in a very lousy world.  Because, don't forget, dear, you won't always have me with you, will you...?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: No, I won't...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: This Dallas boy must be good for you.  Why not bring him around today, before the show?  This time I'll clean my glasses for a better look.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: I'm not sure I can reach him in time.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: By the way, what's your beef against little Sidney?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: When I'm certain, I'll let you know...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: A man couldn't ask for a squarer shake.  No, don't explain your point of view, but...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: "I was reminded of it this morning, when I noticed that the birds had gone South.  We want the same kind of freedom for ourselves - that's what the man said!  A man has the right to face his accusers!  That's the American Way! Who said?  The man said!  From..."

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Burton, don't stand around.  If I go over I'll cut some items off the tail...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: "From Washington through to Jefferson, from Lincoln and F.D.R. right up to today - the Democratic Way of Life!  That's what the man said!  Nowadays it doesn't export to well...  Let's never forget it, ladies and gentlemen."

Speaker: mildred tam
Dialogue: That's grand, just grand, J.J.!  Is my makeup all right?  You know, despite the scads of movies I've made, I've never appeared on TV yet...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Mary, help Miss Tam - anything she wants; she's our star today.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: I got that boy coming over here.  What's so funny?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: With a pocket fulla firecrackers - good.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: I think you loused this up but good. If I can trust my eyes, and I think I can, Susie knows all about your dirty work.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Can't hurt...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Can't hurt?  I had to get him back his job.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Look, J.J., we can wrap this up in one neat bundle, addressed to the dumps - to oblivion.  We're going great, but please play it my way. I cased this kid. Know his ins and outs...He's fulla juice and vinegar, just begging for some big shot like you to give him a squeeze.  Do little Sidney a favor: squeeze! - You know, J.J. - the porcupine bit - needles.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: But it's too late.  I got him back the job...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: No, that's the point - he won't accept your favor!  The manager yes, but not the boy.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Well he's got her in a tizzy, I'll tell you that!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Sure, he steams her up - wants her to stand on her own two feet and all that jazz!

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: And who's feet is she on now?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Presumably yours...  That's according to St. Dallas.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: What's this boy got that Susie likes?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Integrity - acute, like indigestion.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: What does that mean - integrity?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: It's a new wrinkle to tell the truth... I never thought I'd make a killing on some guy's "integrity".

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Full of beans, ain't you?  But you know that you'll stand or fall by what you're doing now...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Calculated risk.  Only we happen to know, J.J., that you like me.  I'm your star pupil -- I reflect back to you your own talent.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: I wouldn't like to take a bite of you; you're a cookie full of arsenic.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I still think he's responsible for the smear.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I guess you're right, but -

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Steve, before we go in - I'd like to...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Hey, Susie - This is a real surprise -- not one but three. J.J.'s just finishing up his rehearsal.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Looks like a wedding.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Steve, you remember my brother...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Well, son, looks like you went out and bought yourself a packet of trouble...

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: You've been very kind about it, Mr. Hunsecker. HUNSECKER Give Susie credit for that.  I took her word that there was nothing to the smear.  Matter of fact, I'll have my say about smears on the show today.  That's why I'd like YOUR personal assurance, too.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Mr. Hunsecker, there's nothing to that smear.  You have my sincere word...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Be good to my kid sister...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Yeah, she's had a peck of trouble for a kid...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Susie likes to keep her girlish secrets.  But in her heart of hearts I imagine, Dallas, that she fancies you in an uncommon way. Now, what about YOU, son?  Not just tom-catting around...I hope?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: J.J., Steve isn't...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Take it easy, Susie.  He wouldn't be much of a man if he didn't understand my concern.  Would you, son?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: No, I wouldn't...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Serious as a deacon...I like it.  I like your style, son!  In a world of old rags and bones, I like it! For instance, take Sidney.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Don't amplify.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Frank, you don't listen!  J.J. just told you to shut your mouth!

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Don't you think it's about time you shut yours?  Who are you to tell a man like Frank D'Angelo to shut up?!

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Does he have to be here in our hair?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Why, has he bothered you before?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Is it news to you?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Son, lots of people tell me I'm a gifted man, but I still can't see around corners.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: I mean, I know it's a difficult thing to be an artist in this crudest of possible worlds, but --

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Nuts!  I'm not here as an artist! I'm here as an average Joe, who happens to love your sister Susie!

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Well, just be careful you don't knock her down, huh?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Frankly, son, you lost me on that last hill.  Just give us the punch line...

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: No punch line.  Maybe I was just admiring your know-how---yours and Falco's.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Why do you keep coupling me with Falco?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: He's here, isn't he?  Do you think, sir, when he dies he'll go to the dog and cat heaven?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Let's forget cats and dogs and other pseudo-literary remarks--- I'll just lay it on the line!  What about that big rumpus in my office today?  You were there, Frank! Where, according to St. Dallas, J.J. was responsible for the Elwell smear!

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Don't go wild, Sidney.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Wild?  Take a look at them and see who's wild...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: What about that...?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: How did you mean it...?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Both of you keep quiet!  Come on, let's go!  Let's go!...

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I don't take kindly to you and Falco selling me ethics.  Who's the injured party here, you?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Right now you're in no position to ask questions!  And your snide remarks---

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Wait a minute, I haven't handed over punishing privileges to you YET!  Put the whip down and I might respect what you're saying...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Susie, did you know about this accusation...?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Or will I be hearing next that I don't even have my sister's welfare at heart...

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Mr. Hunsecker, you've got more twists than a barrel of pretzels.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Continue please...

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I'm afraid I can't cope with them.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Give him credit---the boy's gall is gorgeous!

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Why don't we hear what Susie has to say?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: That's stout of you, Dallas, but Susie may not care to air her dismal views in public...

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Susie...?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Susie, as always, is free to say anything she thinks.  Go on, dear, say exactly what's on your mind, dear.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Those "dears" sound like daggers. May I suggest that you stop DARING her to speak?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: May I lift my eyebrows?  What is this?  What are you trying to do?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I'm trying to get Susie to stand up to you.  But your manner is so threatening that she's afraid to speak!

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Son, you raise your voice again and you'll be outa here on your golden pratt!

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Steve, if only for my sake, I want this stopped!  And the same goes for you, too, J.J.!

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Susie, I'm sorry if---

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Sometimes I think ALL men are fools!...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: You see, Dallas, a plague on both our houses...  We may have to call this game on account of darkness...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: If looks could kill, I'm dead...

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: No, I don't care about you -- you're fantastic.  My whole interest, if it's not too late, is in Susie...and how to undo what you've done to her...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: And what have I done to her, besides not buy her a new fur coat lately?  Sidney, you were right -- the boy's a dilly.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Why?  Because I don't like the way you toy with human lives? - Your contempt and malice?  Because I won't be the accomplice of your sick ego - and the way it's crippled Susie...?  You think of yourself - you and your column - you see yourself as a national glory...but to me, and thousands of others like me, you and your slimy scandal, your phony patriotics - to me, Mr. Hunsecker, you are a national disgrace!

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Son, I don't fancy shooting mosquitoes with elephant guns.  So suppose you just shuffle along and call it a day...

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: But my day with Susie isn't over yet and--

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Ten'll get you fifty you're playing hookey from a padded cell!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: You did it, J.J., you did it good...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: You in a mood, Susie, to run over to Milgrim's later and buy a few new frocks?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: No.  I'm going home.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Want Sidney to drive you over?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Drive Susie home.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Susie...I...I'd have to take it very much amiss if you ever saw that boy again.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I'll never see him again.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Call Van Cleve.  Tell him he was right.  Tell him I said the Dallas boys are not worthy of his club.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Mary...for Susie's own good...don't give her misplaced sympathy...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: I'll get you a cab...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Get away from me.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: J.J. asked me to drive you over and -

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I told you to leave!  I don't know if Steve'll ever talk to me again and I'm ready to blame it all on you!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Susie...!

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: So that's what "integrity" looks like.  Well, I'm always willing to learn...  How is that slob, D'Angelo, your uncle?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: My mother's side--her brother. That reminds me, J.J., Susie looks run down.  She can stand a vacation and so can you.  People say, "Oh, the great J.J., he's made of iron!", but you can use a rest, guy.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: What are you so chipper about?  If I put a cross on every one of your mistakes, you'd look like a graveyard!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: But not for anything I did today...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Sidney, I know human nature.  Susie lied to me - she'll see that boy again.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: You're right, J.J. - she won't give him up, but it doesn't matter. Because the real "money ball" is the boy, not Susan.  And if --

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: These drinks are warm.

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: You said you like to have them on your table.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: What are you a critic?

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: I'll change --

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Forget it.  The real money ball is the boy...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Yeah, the boy...we're on the verge of a farce, a real farce.  As I see it, if Susie had stood behind him today he might have proved a threat. But since primarily he's wedded to his work, he's not going to be able to take it.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Stop tinkering, pal - that horse radish won't jump a fence!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: In brief, J.J., it's all over because any hour now the boy will give her up.  Is it a farce or not?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: This syrup you're giving out, Sidney, you pour over waffles, not J.J. Hunsecker!  What do you mean that lousy kid will give up my sister?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Are you listening?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: How does it matter who's sister? The main thing, they're through and -

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Am I supposed to forget how that boy talked to me today?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: J.J., is he worthy of a second glance from a man like you?  Is he, I mean?...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Brief epitaph: "The boy was talking when he should have been listening."  Bite on this.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Steamship tickets? HUNSECKER  For the next sailing of the Mary. Susan's run down - she's never been abroad and as you so cogently put it, I'm not made of iron.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: That's good.  Now that louse is outa Susie's hair for good.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: I want that boy taken apart.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Why do something that would drive them right back into each other's arms?  Not to mention that this time Susie would know who shot the arrow...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: She knows now.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Why give her real proof?  You nearly ruined her with her first husband - and you were right, J.J., - but she almost followed him out the window.  What do you want - a chronic invalid?

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: I know how to handle Susie.  You just handle the boy, Sidney...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Why, what's tomorrow - a holiday?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: I think I'll go home - maybe I left my sense of humor in another suit.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: You've got that God-given brain - learn to use it!  Do you think it's a personal matter with me, this boy? Are you telling me I see things in terms of personal pique?  Don't you see that today that boy wiped his feet on the choice, on the predilections of sixty million men and women of the greatest country in the world!  If you had any morals yourself, you would understand the immorality of that boy's stand today!  It was not me he criticized - it was my readers!...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: I'm leaving, J.J....

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Don't remove the gangplank, Sidney; you may wanna get back on board.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: This crab gumbo - terrific!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: J.J., it's one thing to wear your dog collar...but when it gets to be a noose...I'd rather have my freedom.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: The man in jail is always for freedom.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Except, if you'll excuse me, I'm not in jail.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Sure you're in jail, Sidney. You're a prisoner of your own fears, of your own greed and ambition; you're in jail.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: J.J.  If you're trying to -

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: You, little boy, don't know who you are!  Talking around corners with the big shots, ten dollar dinners - fourteen suits and cashmere coats - you tell yourself THAT'S who you are!  Later you won't know who you are without a penthouse on upper Park!  But underneath it all, ratting around from day to day, you DO know who you are!  You're a fearful, ignorant nobody - a poor wop kid from the slums of Philly - hoping nobody else finds it out!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: A little hunch occurs to me - you have just painted a self-portrait. You know who YOU are because you scare people - that's what you've got against this boy.  He -

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: I told you what I want you to do tonight!

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: You're blind, Mr. Magoo.  This is a crossroads for me.  I won't get Kello.  Not for a life-time pass to the Polo Grounds.  Not if you serve me Ingrid Bergman on a plate.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Sidney, I told you -

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: If you gave me your COLUMN I wouldn't do a thing like that...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: And who do you think writes the column while Susie and I are away for three months?...

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: Thank you, Sidney.

Speaker: hunsecker
Dialogue: And, Sidney, I'll have that piece of paper back...

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: She'll be down in a minute.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: She didn't say.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I doubt that it matters any more.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Good evening, Mr. D'Angelo.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Hello, Steve.  I'm glad you could come.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Why did you call me?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Would you buy me a cup of coffee? In there...

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: We're on our way to Robard's for a benefit.  I've only got five minutes...

Speaker: counterman
Dialogue: Too late for service.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Just two cups of java.

Speaker: counterman
Dialogue: We serve here only moka coffee.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Make it moke.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Steve...what you tried to do today...you tried to take me up on a high mountain...I couldn't go all the way...I failed you...  Have I lost you, Steve?  Have I...?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Well, maybe I was wrong, too... But there's no doubt, Susie, that we have to face some serious things...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: No one's ever stood up to my brother the way you did.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: But you didn't do much about it, Susie.  You walked out, and there I was...solo...and not too good at that.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I just didn't think that I could antagonize him, Steve -- for OUR sake, I mean.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Susie, I was there for OUR sake, too.  But what a world it would be if we were all afraid to learn to walk and talk because it might offend poppa!  By the way, I think your brother was completely responsible for the smears...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Steve, I...

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: But I don't care about that now. He knew what he was doing today. He was laying down the conditions under which he MIGHT consent to our marriage - if I would bend to every whim of his, like Sidney!  I couldn't do that, Susie...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: You're saying goodbye, aren't you?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: No!  I'm saying that for your sake you have to make a clean break with your brother!

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: But, please, Steve, please - one step at a time!  I was born only yesterday!...

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I told your brother I couldn't be his accomplice.  I can't be yours either, Susie, and encourage him to go on pulverizing you.  I know what type - he's my old man all over again!

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: This beautiful coat is more than just a coat... I hate it!  It's a mink straight-jacket!

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Steve, I feel exhausted...what do you want me to do?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Not what you're doing now.  At least don't ask me - don't ask him. You're fighting for your life! What do YOU want to do?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: You are saying goodbye, aren't you...?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: That's fish four days old...!  I can't buy it, Susie!  Right out of that mouth I love, like you're a ventriloquist's dummy, your BROTHER is saying goodbye!  Gee!...you want me to be honest, don't you?!

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: No, Steve, I don't.  I don't.  Not if it KILLS me I don't!...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Let's not talk any more...you have to go...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Goodbye, Mr. D'Angelo.  Take care of Steve.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Say something funny...Mr. Hasenfeffer.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Look back, Frank, see if she's still standing there...

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Frank, I don't want to make the benefit.  They'll be jammin' all night, and the way I feel -- I'd like to be alone -- I'd like just to walk and walk and never come back.

Speaker: robard
Dialogue: I'm sorry to hear it.

Speaker: robard
Dialogue: I like that boy, Frank.  Anything he does is okay with me...

Speaker: kello
Dialogue: What's all the rush?  You said three o'clock.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: He's leaving early.  After this "set".  He'll be out in a couple of minutes...

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: One of the lieutenant's "surprise parties", I think.

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Can't you wait up the block?  It's not going to look so good, right in front of the club...

Speaker: kello
Dialogue: It's nice, Sidney, that you give me this tip...

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: - He's got them on him.

Speaker: kello
Dialogue: ...And he's got them on him.  I appreciate a thing like that - I appreciate where you are looking out for the virtue of the city.

Speaker: kello
Dialogue: What's your hurry, Snooks?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Take your hands off, Kello...

Speaker: kello
Dialogue: Murph, how do you like this face? Why, I'll be darned -- it's melting! Something got you scared, Sidney...? Listen, rectify me a certain thing. Wasn't you kidding, Snooks, when you told J.J. I was fat...?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Sleep in peace, Kello -- you're skinny -- but J.J. says you sweat!

Speaker: kello
Dialogue: Is that a fact?  He's a dilly, ain't he?  By the by, what did he have against this boy?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: He goes out with girls.

Speaker: kello
Dialogue: Well, I'll be darned.  And what does J.J. think he SHOULD do?

Speaker: sidney
Dialogue: Go out with DIFFERENT girls!

Speaker: kello
Dialogue: I get the peculiar impression, Snooks, that you don't like me. Could I be wrong?

Speaker: sidney
